div.p: DISPLACE THINGS TOGETHER INTO ONE PLACE.

1. The most current general term for the temporary assembling of things is jù 聚 (ant. sàn 散 "spread") which can refer to the gathering together of what does not necessarily belong together and of what is not necessarily of the same kind and what will disperse or be dispersed.
2. Liǎn 斂 (ant. sàn 散 "spread") refers to a human action of assembling things, prototypically taxes or the like, for future use.

3. Shí 拾 "pick up" and qǔ 取 "pick, take" can come to refer to the gathering together for future use articles of common use, but occasionally these words can also take abstract objects in which case the nuance of gathering these for future use is retained.
收集 is the current modern word for gathering things together or collecting things.

rough draft to BEGIN TO identify synonym group members for analysis, based on CL etc. 18.11.2003. CH ／

άγείρω vb. | impf. ήγειρον, ep. άγειρον | aor. ήγειρα, ep.
άγειρα, ep.lpl.subj. άγείρομεν || mid.: ep.3pl. άγέρονται
(AR.), ep.inf. άγέρεσθαι (Od., unless aor.2 άγερέσθαι) | aor.l
ptcpl. (w.act.sens.) άγειράμενος (AR.) | ep.aor.2: 3pl.
άγέροντο (unless impf.), ptcpl. άγρόμενος | ep.3pl.plpf.
άγηγέρατο || pass.: aor. (w.mid.sens.) ήγέρθην, ep. άγέρθην,
3pl. ήγερθεν, ep. άγερθεν |
1 cause to assemble, gather together —people, armies,
animals, or sim. Hom. Hdt. S. E. Th. Pl. +; (also aor.l mid.) AR.
2 || mid. and aor.pass. (of people, gods, animals) gather
together, assemble Hom. Hes. hHom. Call. AR.
3 collect (usu. by requesting fr. others) —goods, gifts,
money, or sim. Od. Hdt. E. D. AR. Plu.; (of a beggar) —pieces of
bread Od.; (of a bird) —food (for its young) Theoc. || mid.
hold a collection Od.
4 (specif., of women, a begging priestess) collect gifts or
alms —w.dat./or deities Kfr. Hdt. PL; (of women engaging
in ritual play at a festival, a man masquerading as a priest)
take a collection (fr. bystanders) Plu. | cf. αγύρτης
5 (fig.) put together —a series of tales Δ.; (of a whirlwind)
gather up —a dust-storm S.(cj., see αίρω 9)
6 || aor.pass. (of a person’s spirit) be rallied —w.prep.phr.
in their chest or heart Hom.

bibl.title: A Dictionary of Selected Synonyms in the Principal Indo-European Languages

note.p: CONGERIES hominum, Caetus; lignorum, Strues; Lapidum aut terrae, Agger; Congeries rerum majorum Cumulus; minorum, Acervus; pecorum Agmen, minorum Grex; majorum Armentum; Fluidorum Confluxus; Sordidorum, Colluvies etc.

bibl.title: Handbook of Greek Synonymes, from the French of M. Alex. Pillon, Librarian of the Bibliothèque Royale , at Paris, and one of the editors of the new edition of Plaché's Dictionnaire Grec-Français, edited, with notes, by the Rev. Thomas Kerchever Arnold, M.A. Rector of Lyndon, and late fellow of Trinity College, Cambridge
A New Dictionary of Classical Greek Synonyms

sense.def: collect (money for a purpose) HYDCD: 1. 募集；招求。
concourse; flow together; only used of the confluence of streams
pick, gather (firewood); get hold of (what one needs)
get things; get what one needs

entry.def: Hé 合 (ant. sàn 散 "spread") is to bring together for a time what does belong together as a group.

sense.def: assemble, call together (the feudal lords), convoke 九合諸侯
to gather at the contextually determinate place

entry.def: Bìng 并 (ant. fēn 分 "separate into different parts") is to bring together things (e.g. troops) for a certain purpose.

sense.def: gather together, hoard, round up; gather (troops etc); unite
be rounded up, be driven together (like cattle)
to collect; to gather together (and not use)
be gathered together (in their propoer place, instead of being distributed and used)
gather together (instead of using) the contextually determinate things

entry.def: Shí 拾 "pick up" and qǔ 取 "pick, take" can come to refer to the gathering together for future use articles of common use, but occasionally these words can also take abstract objects in which case the nuance of gathering these for future use is retained.

sense.def: ZZ: gather (acorns and chestnuts); HF: pick up in the street (lost items), pick up (a silkworm)
gather, collect; pick up with one's bare hands
be picked up > by dominated by; be lured off ????

entry.def: Shōu 收, which always has humans subjects, is to admit into a pre-existing assembly of things permanently or for a time.

sense.def: assemble; garner; take in, allow to join; gather in; gather up, gather together (one's things)
be allowed to join, be collected

entry.def: Liǎn 斂 (ant. sàn 散 "spread") refers to a human action of assembling things, prototypically taxes or the like, for future use.

sense.def: 萬物之總: the point where Ns gather, the one in whose hands Ns gather

entry.def: The most current general term for the temporary assembling of things is jù 聚 (ant. sàn 散 "spread") which can refer to the gathering together of what does not necessarily belong together and of what is not necessarily of the same kind and what will disperse or be dispersed.

The most current general term for the temporary assembling of things is jù 聚 (ant. sàn 散 "spread") which can refer to the gathering together of what does not necessarily belong together and of what is not necessarily of the same kind and what will disperse or be dispersed.

sense.def: mostly of persons, but occasionally also of things like insects: assemble
assemble persons or things; amass; gather around oneself
to become assembled; to become dense and abundant (of population);
gather the contextually determinate objects N
gather N1 in the place N2
poetic and archaic, SHI 1: gather (vegetables etc.)
get together, gather as a group or a unit
converge on, concentrate the military forces on
SHU, collect, store up; stud with

entry.def: Jí 集 (ant. sàn 散 "spread") is to form a group, flock, or unit, and when used transitively, the word does not tend to take concrete objects in the manner of jī 積. See ACCUMULATE.

sense.def: (both of humans and of things) assemble SHIJI 百鬼集矣"all the ghosts and spirits had already assembled"
cause to be assembled > collect together > compile
bring together, gather (a group of people)
